message_1:
The question is:

How many ways are there to form a committee of 5 people out of 10 people, if one of the 10 people must be the chairperson of the committee?
message_2:
Since one of the 10 people must be the chairperson, we first choose the chairperson. There are 10 ways to choose the chairperson (10 choices for 1 position).

After choosing the chairperson, we need to choose the remaining 4 members of the committee from the remaining 9 people. This can be done using combinations, as the order of the members does not matter.

The number of ways to choose 4 members from 9 people is given by the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

In this case, n = 9 and k = 4:

C(9, 4) = 9! / (4!(9-4)!)
C(9, 4) = 9! / (4!5!)
C(9, 4) = 362880 / (24 * 120)
C(9, 4) = 362880 / 2880
C(9, 4) = 126

So there are 126 ways to choose the remaining 4 members.

Now, we multiply the number of ways to choose the chairperson (10) by the number of ways to choose the remaining members (126):

Total ways = 10 * 126 = 1260

There are 1260 ways to form a committee of 5 people out of 10 people, with one of them being the chairperson.
